abstract.p: Bertelsmann, already fighting free distribution of music in court, is now fighting it over Internet with its own online music distribution strategy; company's record label, BMG Entertainment, says it will make singles and albums available over Internet for digital download (S)

block.p: Bertelsmann, already fighting the free distribution of music in court, is now fighting it over the Internet -- with its own online music distribution strategy. The company's record label, BMG Entertainment, said it would make singles and albums available over the Internet for digital download. BMG started the service on Lycos.com, offering 100 singles and albums from artists including Christina Aguilera, Toni Braxton and Santana. Unlike Napster, the free music exchange service that the record labels are challenging in court, BMG's digital downloads come at a price: $1.98 to $3.49 for singles and $9.98 to $14.98 for albums. The company said it planned to make 2,500 albums and singles available by the holiday season on a variety of Web sites.
